column4: Do you people realise that I've NEVER EVER had a question answered in this channel!!! And it's been at least 50 questions and counting
Do you have a question now? Maybe you can get a new record of 51 unanswered questions :)
what is the answer to life?
Dude, even google knows that: http://www.google.com/search?q=answer+to+life%2C+the+universe%2C+and+everything
Where did you tell the installer to install grub's boot sector, did Ubuntu's installer give any error messages, and what is the exact error message from grub?
They can all be btrfs, but understand that btrfs is still experimental and if you want a stable reliable system it's probably not worth it to use btrfs yet.

I can't remember the exact error messages: The first time it 'booted' to a grub recovery console after an uncertain error message about cannot find drive with uuid awe123uie123 (or something alike) and the second time it was just "cannot find drive, please insert drive" - ubuntu installer gave no problems
grub never asks to insert a drive, so that must have been something else printing that error.
yeah I know, it must have been a problem with the MBR and the ?bios printed that last one? I don't know
bekks let's simplify this: something went wrong with the following choices: sda1 /home  btrfs, sdb1 / btrfs; MBR on sda... why did this not work?
I would need to know the exact error messages from grub, and probably also see boot info script output, to tell you.
the one I got most of the time was: Cannot find device with UUID xxxxxx then next line: grub>
What version of Ubuntu did you try to install?
isn't it that / may be btrfs but /boot must still be ext4
grub has full support for btrfs, including /boot/.
should the MBR be on sda or sda1?
definitely sda.
Well, sda or sdb, but certainly not a partition like sda1 or sdb1.
and for some reason the advanced partitioning tool left 1mb free space before the sda1 partition (this cannot be avoided)
That's because aligning to MiB boundaries is the right thing to do for performance reasons.
thanks I am learning a lot now; One more thing: what fs is the "best" for use on a ssd?
Right now, for most use cases, probably ext4.
